properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Early this evening, conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing damaging wind gusts and producing large hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T04:02:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T20:35:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3512381391.2019
Area: Joutel - Matagami area, Miquelon - Desmaraisville area, La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Qu√©villon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area

properties.Title: Update: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Town of Marshall. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Town of Marshall water system. This advisory has been extended and will remain in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-09-27T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Marshall, 2019-09-25T12:55:15-06:00, F440D819-ED0D-8EA0-A949-1891178129EB
Area: Town of Marshall
properties.Author: SK Marshall

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long duration snowfall event starting the afternoon of Friday September 27 through Monday September 30 is anticipated for parts of southwestern Alberta as a moisture laden Pacific weather system tracks through the area. There is still uncertainty around snowfall accumulations as warm surface temperatures will melt initial snowfall. Current indications suggest that by Monday, total accumulations of 15 to 30 cm over portions of southwestern Alberta are possible. For the extreme southwest corner of the province, upslope flow will enhance snowfall along higher terrain with localized snowfall totals of over 50 cm possible by Monday. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Take frequent breaks and avoid strain when clearing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T13:33:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T21:34:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0534343317.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Overnight temperatures are expected to drop to zero degrees celsius or below for parts of northern Alberta, resulting in patchy frost. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T13:32:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T21:33:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0530424173.2019

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Ground temperatures will cool to near freezing over most regions of New Brunswick tonight. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 5:17 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of thunderstorms is located from Iroquois Falls northward towards Kesagami Provincial Park. The line is weakening as it moves east at 60 km/h. Locations impacted include: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park, Iroquois Falls, Matheson, Barbers Bay, Fielding, Potter, Tunis, Shillington, Monteith, Watabeag and Kirke. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-09-26T01:15:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T21:18:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2322031656.2019
Area: Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. North winds have strengthened to 60 gusting 80 km/h early this evening, and will likely reach the warning threshold of 70 gusting 90 before diminishing slightly in the late overnight hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T10:39:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-26T00:24:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3942404947.2019
Area: Baker Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall of 30 to 60 mm expected, with locally higher amounts possible. Rain, at times heavy, will taper off tonight over southwestern Newfoundland but will continue over southeastern Newfoundland until tapering off to isolated showers Thursday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-09-26T10:29:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T18:30:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3293070210.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds occurring over this area will diminish overnight. Winds will however increase tomorrow evening to 100 kilometres per hour. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T11:18:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T19:19:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2492358736.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Moist southeasterly winds blowing off of Hudson Bay continue in the Coral Harbour area, creating fog, especially in the overnight and morning hours. Visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected to redevelop this evening and more or less persist through most of Thursday morning. Visibilities should improve somewhat Thursday afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-26T12:18:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-25T20:19:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2862667631.2019
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada
